subject: Re: another lengthy post about ebay in answer to margaret

> > Hi Bruce. I don't see this so much as an assault on anyone, as it 
> is simply bringing awareness into a forum (ebay) where it is 
> desperately needed. Was it not you who recently stated sellers who 
> take advantage of others in this way are "no more than thieves 
> without guns" and "should not be patronized no matter the 
> circumstances." You have characterized them as "wolves" and "demons" 
> but now are saying "do nothing." Which, honestly, I could understand 
> if my suggestion was coming from a place of vengeance. It is 
> not.THIS IS ABOUT EDUCATION FIRST AND FOREMOST, and standing up for 
> those who are, unknowingly, being taken advantage of. The byproduct 
> of providing this education will be allowing consumers to make an 
> informed decision and if that hurts the sales of unscrupulous 
> sellers, then so be it. Ann has just echoed some of my remarks in 
> earlier posts in support of sellers rights to take advantage of the 
> market ... that some people may find it's worth it to pay more to 
> someone to receive a previously hacked unit. I would venture to 
> guess, this educational information will A) help prevent those who 
> are capable of doing the hack themselves from being duped, and B) 
> force sellers who do offer pre-hacked units to do so for a 
> more 'reasonable' fee. This is neither spiteful nor aggressive, and 
> it's certainly not any kind of vengeance driven on my part. It's 
> standing up for the uninformed, leveling the playing field for 
> sellers, and it's bringing more people the knowledge that 
> doing 'box' research is not an exclusive club that only the rich can 
> take part in (and given the pricing on the bids for these units, 
> people are under the false assumption that you have a pay a high 
> price to get your hands on a limited resource, when that simply is 
> not the case.)I can see nothing but positive benefits coming from 
> educating people about their options.Margaret--- In EVP-
